FlashAttention(2): The native attention and its constraints

12 Feb 2026

The "Standard" Attention (The Wasteful Way)

Let's look at the standard calculation:

The fundamental problem with standard attention is that the attention matrix doesn't fit in SRAM (on-chip memory).

For a sequence length of N=4096N=4096N=4096﻿ with FP16:

  • Attention matrix size: 40962×2 bytes=32MB4096^2 × 2 \space bytes = 32 MB40962×2 bytes=32MB﻿
  • SRAM size per SM: 192 KB

Since 32MB>>192KB,32 MB >> 192 KB,32MB>>192KB,﻿ the attention matrix cannot be kept on-chip. Thus it must be stored in HBM.

A naive implementation performs attention in three separate kernel launches, materializing intermediate results in HBM each time:

  1. MatMul (S=QKTS = Q K^TS=QKT﻿):
    • Load Q,KQ, KQ,K﻿ from HBM to SRAM.
    • Compute SSS﻿ (Score Matrix, size N×NN \times NN×N﻿).
    • WRITE SSS﻿ to HBM. (Huge write).
  1. Softmax (P=softmax(S)P = \text{softmax}(S)P=softmax(S)﻿):
    • READ SSS﻿ from HBM.
    • Compute Exponentials/Sum.
    • WRITE PPP﻿ to HBM. (Huge write).
  1. MatMul (O=PVO = P VO=PV﻿):
    • READ PPP﻿ from HBM.
    • Load VVV﻿.
    • Compute Output.
    • Write Output to HBM.

Numerical instability in standard softmax

The "Numerical Instability" of Standard Softmax comes down to the physical limitations of how computers store numbers (Floating Point Arithmetic).

In pure mathematics, e1000e^{1000}e1000﻿ is just a very large number. In a computer (using float32), e1000e^{1000}e1000﻿ is an error.

Here are the two specific ways Standard Softmax crashes your training: Overflow and Underflow.

The Explosion (Overflow) - The Most Common Crash

The standard formula is:

float32 Range: ±1.2×10−38±1.2 \times 10^{-38}±1.2×10−38﻿ to ±3.4×1038±3.4 \times 10^{38}±3.4×1038﻿

  • The Overflow Threshold: e88.7≈3.4×1038e^{88.7} ≈ 3.4 \times 10^{38}e88.7≈3.4×1038﻿ (the maximum)
  • Anything larger becomes inf

The Scenario:
Imagine your attention score (dot product) is 100. (This is common in unscaled attention).

  1. Calculate Numerator: e100e^{100}e100﻿.
  1. Computer says: "That is bigger than 103810^{38}1038﻿. I will call it Infinity (inf)."
  1. Calculate Denominator: Sum of infinities = Infinity.
  1. Result:

Result: Your gradients turn to NaN, and your loss becomes NaN. The training run is dead.

The Vanishing (Underflow) - The Division by Zero

This happens when numbers are very negative.

The Physics:

  • float32 Limit: The smallest positive number is roughly 1.2×10−381.2 \times 10^{-38}1.2×10−38﻿.
  • The Threshold: e−88e^{-88}e−88﻿ is roughly the limit. Anything smaller becomes 0.0.

The Scenario:
Imagine your input vector is [-100, -200, -300].

  1. Calculate Numerators:
    • e−100→0.0e^{-100} \to 0.0e−100→0.0﻿
    • e−200→0.0e^{-200} \to 0.0e−200→0.0﻿
    • e−300→0.0e^{-300} \to 0.0e−300→0.0﻿
  1. Calculate Denominator: Sum of zeros = 0.0.
  1. Result:

This is rarer, but it happens if you use heavy masking (setting scores to −1e9-1e9−1e9﻿) and mess up the logic slightly.

The Solution: "Safe Softmax" (Shift-Invariance)

To fix this, we use the property that Softmax is Shift Invariant. If you add or subtract a constant CCC﻿ from every input, the result does not change.

The Trick: We choose C=max⁡(x)C = \max(x)C=max(x)﻿.

Let's retry the Overflow Scenario (x=[100,90,80]x = [100, 90, 80]x=[100,90,80]﻿) using this trick:

  • Max m=100m = 100m=100﻿.
  • Shifted inputs: [0,−10,−20][0, -10, -20][0,−10,−20]﻿.
  1. Numerators:
    • e0=1.0e^0 = 1.0e0=1.0﻿ (Safe)
    • e−10≈0.000045e^{-10} \approx 0.000045e−10≈0.000045﻿ (Safe)
    • e−20≈0.000000002e^{-20} \approx 0.000000002e−20≈0.000000002﻿ (Safe)
  1. Denominator: 1.0+0.000045+⋯≈1.0000451.0 + 0.000045 + \dots \approx 1.0000451.0+0.000045+⋯≈1.000045﻿.
  1. Result:

Why is it stable?

  1. The largest term becomes e0=1e^0 = 1e0=1﻿. It never overflows.
  1. The denominator is always at least 111﻿ (from the max term). It never underflows to zero.

This is why m (the global maximum) is absolutely required in the FlashAttention Online Softmax calculation. It anchors the math in the "Safe Zone" of floating-point numbers.

Summary: Safe Softmax Algorithm
